data.name: Young Women's Music Project
data.desc: The Young Women's Music Project (YWMP) provides an inclusive and supportive space for young women aged 14-21 to make music together, learn new skills, express themselves, and grow in confidence. In free music sessions and workshops, the young women make and record music, plan and hold gigs and events. These projects help young people to challenge issues affecting them in a creative and productive way, such as class, race, sexuality, gender, mental health, and consent.

data.name: Wolvercote Sunday Market
data.desc: This is a small weekly market run by volunteers and held in a community-run pub. It offers local organic eggs, a range of organic vegetables and fruits (from local sources whenever possible), sourdough breads and cakes made from organic flour, plus (visiting the market at various intervals from fortnightly to monthly) other local products like jams, Italian and Greek foods, cured meats, knitted clothing, plants, etc., plus services such as the local councillors' surgery. The pub provides Sunday breakfast, teas and coffees, meanwhile.

data.name: We Own It
data.desc: We Own It’s mission is to end privatisation for good so that people come before profit. We believe public services should belong to all of us - whether that's the NHS, schools, water, energy, rail, Royal Mail, care work or council services. Our work focuses on two things: campaigning against privatisation, and making the case for public ownership.
data.street: The Old Music Hall;106-108 Cowley Road

data.name: Transition Chipping Norton
data.desc: Sustainble community solutions - practical intiatives for a thriving, sustainable future for our town

data.name: Transition by Design
data.desc: Oxford based architecture & design cooperative. Specialising in green architecture, Passivhaus, community-led housing, participatory design and meanwhile use.

data.name: Tolhurst Organic Partnership
data.desc: Tolhurst Organic is a farm specialised in local fruit and veg. The food produced here is the product of an entire journey. The journey is one which deeply involves many people who come here, creates a model for Stockfree Organic farming, supports an idyllic rural lifestyle and provides soul food for those who work here and good food for ourselves and our families. Our aim is not to supply every family in the south but to farm with an emphasis on education and conservation. Our farming system not only helps to minimise harmful effects on the environment but feeds you and your family as well.
data.street: The Packing Shed;Hardwick Estate Walled Garden

data.name: The Village - Childcare Collective
data.desc: The Village is a collective of 15 families who care for one another's children - like a childcare "time bank". This offers free, flexible, trusted and community-based childcare to families.

data.name: The RED Learning Coop: Research, Education and Development for Social Change
data.desc:
The RED Learning Cooperative brings together practitioners and activists with many years of experience of working with Trade Unions, Non-Governmental Organisations, Social Enterprises, Charities, Community groups and the Cooperative Movement. We have a passion for working collaboratively to develop critically reflective, radical education.
We offer research and education, for personal and collective agency and empowerment.

data.name: The Children's Allotment
data.desc:
We are a community group creating an inclusive outdoor education space for the local community in the East Ward Allotments on Cricket Rd. Our focus is on providing cooperative childcare, outdoor learning and growing for families and children.

.

data.name: Tap Social Movement Ltd.
data.desc: Tap Social is a social enterprise craft brewery that provides training and employment to people currently serving or recently released from prison sentences to help reduce reoffending and turn lives around. Our taproom is open to the public every day and features live music, street food, festivals, community events, yoga, seminars and more.
data.street: Tap Social, Unit 27 Curtis Industrial Estate;North Hinksey Lane

data.name: Tandem Collective
data.desc:
Tandem Collective believes the arts have a powerful role to play in enacting positive change on social and environmental issues. Tandem has grown out of a network of committed volunteers who came together to create the first Tandem Festival in 2014. Tandem is now an organisation reaching beyond the festival to create and facilitate inspiring, nourishing and developmental events and activities throughout the year.

Tandem Collective manages a wide range of events and collaborative projects that fuse volunteering opportunities, workshops, talks and skill-sharing with creative mediums including music, art, theatre, literature, cinema and dance. Our key projects are Ethno England, Tandem Skills Camp, InTandem with…, InTandem Publications and Tandem Festival. Tandem facilitates collaborations between artists, researchers, activists and campaign groups on local, national and international scales.

data.name: Talking Shop
data.desc:
We are a community volunteer group based at Sandford-on-Thames' Village Hall. 
We run a cafe, convenient shop & community activities in our bright airy space.
We've got car parking, a lovely garden and a gate straight into the playground. 
We also have a volunteer bike mechanic team ​& a Good Neighbour network who match up volunteers offering support, lifts, companionship, with residents in need.

data.name: Syrian Sisters
data.desc: Syrian Sisters is a regular support group for women from Syria and other Arabic-speaking countries. We meet every Friday at Rose Hill Community Centre. We run workshops and training on everything from learning English to Zumba classes. We also have activities for children during the holidays and host regular meals and celebrations.

data.name: South Oxford Farmers and Community Market
data.desc: The South Oxford Farmers and Community Market (SOFACOMA) is a weekly market selling ethically-produced local, seasonal and/or organic food and non-food goods. We define ‘local’ as being produced within a 30-mile radius of Oxford; and ‘produced’ as containing a significant quantity of local ingredients and labour. The South Oxford Farmers and Community Market is an initiative of the Low Carbon South Oxford (LCSO) Sustainable Food Group which supports the promotion of local food as a way of helping to combat climate change by reducing the amount of carbon released in the transport of food over long distances.

data.name: South Oxford Community Centre
data.desc:
The Community centre is located in a beautiful old Victorian pumping station built in 1856 and can be found a mile from the centre of Oxford just off the Abingdon Road in Lake Street.
South Oxford Community Association (set up in 1937) looks after the day to day running of the Community Centre. We provide rooms for the benefit of local residents to use for leisure, meetings, and learning at affordable prices. The Association is a charity, and we offer subsidised rates for groups working for the benefit of the community. The Community Centre is self-financing and we pay all our own staff costs, bills, buy our equipment and maintain the interior of the building. Our Management Committee is a friendly group, and we are always looking for new members.

data.name: SOMA Housing Co-Operative Ltd
data.desc: It is SOMA's intention to purchase land in order to establish a sustainable community which is made up of "social housing" with tenants living in self built eco homes which they have at an affordable rent. The co-op will also provided support structures that are required and which enable a disabled person to live independently and experience a healthier and more fulfilling life.

data.name: Solidarity Economy Association
data.desc: A not-for-profit that supports and promotes the solidarity economy - organisations, projects and people working to create a socially just and ecologically sustainable world.

data.name: SHARE Oxford - A Library of Things
data.desc: SHARE Oxford aims to make sharing easier and to increase access to good quality things so that we may reduce consumption and waste, save money, save the environment, and feel good about it. We host Oxford’s Library of Things, which allows people to borrow instead of buy items needed only occasionally, like outdoor equipment, DIY tools, cooking implements, and more. We also run regular Repair Cafes where our volunteers fix your broken items to keep them in use for longer.

data.name: SESI Food And Household Refills
data.desc:
SESI is a social enterprise born in 2006 in the shed of our local primary school. In 2007 on demand, we transitioned to running a Zero Waste Pop Up Shop at East Oxford Farmers Market. We help reduce food waste, cut on plastic pollution and thrive in community cohesion.
In 2013 SESI developed its brand of vegan, cruelty free and biodegradable household detergents, manufactured by a family firm 50 miles from Oxford. Over 70 traders across England, Wales, Jersey and Guernsey refill SESI detergents – more joining our circular scheme. Together, we currently refill 25,000 bottles/month and the figure keeps growing.

data.name: Rose Hill Community Cupboard
data.desc: Rose Hill Community Cupboard provides food and essential items to people who need it the most. They help people by serving a cuppa and a snack and sending them home with a loaf and a nutritious bag of fresh fruit and veg. Visitors can chat, colour and play games while waiting to choose some groceries at the drop-in centre at Rose Hill Methodist Church one afternoon a week.
data.street: Rose Hill Methodist Church;34 Singletree;Rose Hill

data.name: Rose Hill Carpet Bowls and New Age Curling
data.desc: Welcome to Rose Hill Carpet Bowls And New Age Curling. This meetup group is for those interested in carpet bowls and / or new age curling and would like to try out a new sport.
data.street: Rose Hill Community Centre ;Carole’s Way;Rose Hill

data.name: Rose Hill and Iffley Low Carbon (RHILC)
data.desc: Rose Hill and Iffley Low Carbon is a Community Action Group that works with others to reduce the carbon footprint of our area and to make it more sustainable. We have worked with the organisations in brackets to: install 190 solar panels on Rose Hill Community Centre (OCC: Oxford City Council), solar PV and battery storage on 76 social homes in Rose Hill (Bioregional and OCC),  solar PV and battery storage on Rose Hill Primary School (Low Carbon Hub), a cycle repair kit (Low Carbon Hub and OCC) and  we run local bike repair workshops (Broken Spoke). We work closely with Rose Hill Primary School to plant trees, conduct assemblies and facilitate education about climate change. We organise Repair Cafes where people can get electrical goods, clothes and bikes mended for free (in cooperation with Rose Hill Community Centre). Wa also organise regular talks, workshops and films to raise awareness of particular aspects of sustainability on One Planet Living principles. Over the past five years, we have thermally imaged over 150 houses to check where heat is leaking out and advise on economic ways to insulate homes (assisted by CAG, the Low Carbon Hub and Bioregional). We are about to cooperate with 'Cosy Homes Oxfordshire' in providing expert insulation advice for individual house-holders. We are also exploring the possibility of heating Rose Hill homes with waste heat from Sainsbury's cooling systems (through Bioregional and OCC).
data.street: Rose Hill Community Centre;Carole’s Way;Rose Hill

data.name: Refill Oxford
data.desc: Refill is a practical campaign that makes refilling your bottle as easy and convenient as possible, with the aim of reducing plastic waste. Participating cafes, bars, restaurants, pubs, galleries, museums and other businesses display a blue Refill sticker in their window to welcome thirsty passers-by to come on in and fill up their water bottle – for free. All the Refill "stations" are marked on an online map. You can download the Refill app to your phone to find out where they all are- https://www.refill.org.uk/get-the-refill-app/.

data.name: Project SOUP
data.desc:
Since its inception in 2013, Project SOUP (Support Oxford's Upcoming Projects) has been committed to combatting local issues and being a driving force for change in the Oxford community. Project SOUP brings together the people behind new community project ideas and the people that want to help make them happen. Together they enable people to support local projects in an effective way via a simple, democratic vote over a delicious dinner, made from surplus food. 
They hold one soup-filling, heart-warming event per Oxford academic term. At each event, 3-4 local social action groups/charities are invited to speak about their work, ‘pitch’ an idea to try and persuade the audience for their vote. After all the votes have been counted, a winner is announced and all the money on the door and extra donations goes directly to them.

data.name: Oxfordshire Social Entrepreneurship Partnership (OSEP)
data.desc: OSEP is a support organisation for Social Enterprise and other organisations making positive social and environmental impact. It has been established as a Community Interest Company by local social entrepreneurs with the support of both Oxford universities and other key local and national stakeholders.

data.name: Oxfordshire Asian Women's Voice
data.desc: Oxfordshire Asian Women's Voice was set up 7 months ago to provide support and advice to Asian women in their native language. We respond to the needs and requests from our members, providing support in a range of areas from learning new skills to accessing services and support against domestic violence.
data.street: Rose Hill Community Centre;Carole’s Way;Rose Hill

data.name: Oxford Wood Recycling
data.desc: Oxford Wood Recycling was established in 2005 to address the sustainability issues surrounding wood waste management in the UK whilst providing employment opportunities for people facing disadvantages to re-enter the workplace. We collect unwanted wood from both commercial and domestic properties that may otherwise end up in landfill. Our reclaimed wood is then cleaned up and offered for sale or made into furniture in our Abingdon workshop - reducing waste and carbon emissions by recycling and up-cycling wood.

data.name: Oxford SU Women’s Campaign
data.desc: The women’s campaign is for all women (trans, cis, and intersex) and non-binary people, including those with complex gender identities who associate in some way with the term woman, as well as those who feel they experience structural misogyny. We organize a range of events from feminist discussion groups and panels to working on lobbying the university and collaborating on demonstrations. All our events are very welcoming and there’s no level of experience or knowledge required or expected to attend. We also hold regular open meetings where women and non-binary students are very welcome. These are a great opportunity for anyone outside our committee to bring ideas and suggestions to us. Our facebook page is the best place to keep up with what we’re doing, to get involved with our events, and to contact us with any inquiries or suggestions.

data.name: Oxford SU LGBTQ+ Campaign
data.desc:
The LGBTQ+ Campaign is the political campaigning arm of Oxford’s queer community. We frequently work alongside the Student Union, LGBTQ+ college reps, and the OU LGBTQ+ Society. We have officers for the majority of the specific identities and intersections of the LGBTQ+ umbrella. We are also keen to work with LGBTQ+ community activist groups based in Oxford. If this is you, please feel free to email us. 

Oxford SU LGBTQ+ Campaign takes a very active role in student life: We oversee the organisation of LGBTQ+ 101 workshops at approximately half of Oxford colleges. We engage in a broad range of events, including protests and demonstrations, engaging with the local community and hosting talks, panel discussions, round tables, social events, and photo campaigns. We also work with the University's and colleges' administration to improve the lives of LGBTQ+ students. 

One of Campaign’s current priorities is fighting transphobia and improving the living and working conditions of transgender students in Oxford. We have conducted a trans survey based on which we are working towards changing policies at both a university and college level to tackle hate speech both broadly and pertaining to specific LGBTQ+ identities.
Feel free to get in contact with us at lgbtq-chair@oxfordsu.ox.ac.uk or by messaging the Facebook page.

data.name: Oxford Stand Up To Racism
data.desc: We are witnessing an unprecedented growth in racism, racist attacks and far right activity.  We aim to mobilse people in protests and campaigns against Islamophobia, antisemitism and racism.  We say Black Lives Matter and oppose the racist scapegoating of migrants and refugees.  We mobilise against fascists whenever they raise their heads.

data.name: Oxford Poetry Library
data.desc: Oxford Poetry Library aims to provide a space in Oxford for people to access and talk about poetry, discover new writing, and be platformed as local writers. As a library, we promote collective ownership, shared resources, and knowledge shared through collaboration in community spaces. It is free to join the library and anyone can borrow books, with no late fees or punishing fines for overdues. We operate out of a big custom-built purple cargo bike, peddling (and pedalling) our wares to farmers markets, festivals, and street events throughout the city for all sorts of people to discover all sorts of poetry. A lot of our work is focused on marginalized groups (such as young people, the homeless and vulnerably housed, and mental health charities), collaborating with other organizations to promote access to literature for people who might not otherwise have it. We also sell zines, books, and magazines created or produced locally and by Oxford writers, run regular events, workshops, and reading groups.

data.name: Oxford Permaculture Picturehouse
data.desc: Oxford Permaculture Picturehouse aims to bring people together around films in sympathy with permaculture, promoting permaculture messages and know-how, but most of all reinforcing the network of interested people. Films are usually screened on the 4th Monday of the month at the East Oxford Community Centre.
data.street: East Oxford Community Centre;44 Princes Street

data.name: Oxford Human Rights Festival
data.desc: The Oxford Human Rights Festival was started as a film festival in 2001 by Oxford Brookes students on the MA Development and Emergency Practice course. The aim of the festival is to raise awareness of human rights issues through the arts. It is now curated by students from across the university and the annual programme includes film and documentary screenings, lectures, workshops, exhibitions, and performances. All events take place at Oxford Brookes University, are free and open to everyone; students, staff and the wider Oxford community.
data.street: c/o School of Architecture;Oxford Brookes University;Headington Campus

data.name: Oxford GreenPrint
data.desc: Oxford GreenPrint is a workers’ co-operative providing ethical, low impact printing to community groups, campaign groups, NGOs and businesses both in Oxford and across the UK. All their printing is done on recycled paper or card using renewable energy.
data.street: East Oxford Community Centre;OARC (Room 1) upstairs;44 Princes Street

data.name: Oxford City Council Co-operatives Champion
data.desc: Oxford City Council appointed Cllr Richard Howlett to act as its Co-operatives Champion in January 2019. The ‘champion’ role is a way for non-executive cllrs to represent the council on areas about which they are passionate. Richard Howlett has worked in co-ops in the city for the past decade and is committed to the growth of the local co-op economy. He convened an ‘advisory group’ of local co-operators who sit around the role to give advice and support and to whom he is accountable.

data.name: Orinoco Scrapstore
data.desc: Orinoco’s mission is to banish boredom and save the planet using creativity and play to inspire the reuse of materials. Over its 25 year history, Orinoco has saved lorry loads of interesting resources from ending up in landfill. Their Scrapstore in Headington sells scrap items for art, crafts, play and creative projects as well as new art materials, refurbished tools and DIY stuff. They collect suitable waste materials from businesses for potential reuse; accept usable garden and workshop tools; and hold a monthly ‘Swap Shop’ on the second Saturday of every month for usable household items people may no longer need or want.

data.name: Open House
data.desc: We’re a public talking shop on housing and homelessness. We like drinking tea, making new friends and talking to strangers about housing. We’re trying to get as many people as possible, especially those without a permanent home, involved in the decisions that are being made about how we house people in Oxford.

data.name: Nishkam SWAT
data.desc: Nishkam SWAT provide outreach services for the homeless and less fortunate. This includes an evening meal and clothing. The service we provide is not tailored to a specific community or ethnic group, we are an all inclusive faith based and value led charity serving all of humanity regardless of caste, creed, colour or faith.

data.name: New Internationalist Publications Ltd
data.desc: New Internationalist is a leading independent media organization dedicated to socially conscious journalism and publishing. They are an independent, not-for-profit media multi-stakeholder co-operative, owned by their workers and over 3,600 investors. They tell the stories that the mainstream media sidestep and offer a platform for the people living those stories. Their award-winning magazine, books and website set the agenda for a radically fairer future, promote global justice and campaign for the disadvantaged all over the world.
data.street: The Old Music Hall;106-108 Cowley Road

data.name: My Life My Choice
data.desc: My Life My Choice is a user-led Oxfordshire based self-advocacy organisation. We raise the self-esteem, confidence and quality of life for people with learning disabilities by providing training, employment, volunteering and social opportunities for our members.

data.name: Low Carbon West Oxford
data.desc: Low Carbon West Oxford (LCWO) was set up after the summer floods of 2007 by residents concerned about climate change and local flooding. It is a community-led initiative which aims to combat climate change by cutting their community’s carbon dioxide emissions by 80 % by 2050, encouraging residents to live more sustainably, and contributing to a more cohesive and resilient community. They seek to work in an inclusive manner and ensure that everyone who lives and works in the area has a chance to participate in and benefit from LCWO’s projects.

data.name: Low Carbon Oxford North
Leys community fridge
data.desc: The Leys community fridge is a fridge in the Blackbird Leys community centre into which anyone can put food, and from which anyone can take food.  In practice, most of the food comes from one large supermarket, and is brought to the fridge by volunteers in their private cars.  The fridge provides fresh fruit, vegetables, bread/pastries, dairy products and eggs for free to residents of the most deprived estate in Oxford.  It is a win-win: it reduces food waste and provides food to people who can really use it.
data.street: Blackbird Leys Community Centre;Blackbird Leys Road

data.name: Kindling Housing Co-operative
data.desc: Kindling Housing Cooperative aims to provide a safe, secure, affordable and supportive environment for generations of politically and socially active individuals. We believe this is even more important at a time when other forms of housing are further out of reach. We aim to provide a productive living space for a diverse group of individuals and help to ensure the continuation of vital radical social and ecological projects for a more equal society. Through this project we are attempting to demonstrate and inspire a different way of living: taking decisions by consensus, taking control of our infrastructure, connecting to the community and ecosystem, whilst being practical, empathic, active and egalitarian.

data.name: InsightShare
data.desc: At InsightShare we work with communities around the world to address key issues through Participatory Video. Our goal if to  amplify unheard voices and bring people together to focus on change.  We therefore encourage, support push and advocate for participation and self-representation so that marginalised communities are part and parcel of decisions that affect their lives.
data.street: The Old Music Hall;106-108 Cowley Road

data.name: Incredible Edible Oxford
data.desc:
We have a number of edible beds around Oxford – consisting of culinary, medicinal herbs, fruit tree guilds and perennial vegetables.
We also have a Forest Garden in Florence Park, showcasing medicinal, pollinator and dye plants, as well as perennial salad leaves.
The beds are used for regular gardening sessions and free workshops, designed to encourage others to grow their own.
We run edible hanging basket events and work with a local secondary school with edible planting.
These activities are funded by three other areas of income generating activity – Nursery, Design and Education.

data.name: Hempen
data.desc: Hempen is a not for profit workers cooperative growing and producing organic hemp into goods for the benefit of people, community and planet.

data.name: Harwell Green Club
data.desc: The Harwell Green Club is a forum for People on and off the Harwell Campus with a shared interest in a Low Carbon Sustainable Future. It aims to bring people of this mind together to share information, make new connections and exchange views, meeting informally the third Thursday of the month, and is open to all.

data.name: Hand me on maternity, baby & toddler kit Oxford
data.desc: We are an online community that share and pass on pre-loved maternity, baby and toddler clothes, toys and equipment for free.

data.name: Hand me on 3-8yrs kid's stuff Oxford
data.desc: We are an online community that share and pass on pre-loved maternity, baby and toddler clothes, toys and equipment for free.

data.name: Good Food Oxford
data.desc: Good Food Oxford is a network for a better food system in Oxford. It is open to anyone with an interest in food and food production and aims to bring together citizens, local authorities, businesses, academics and other stakeholders to help us all work together towards the shared goal of healthy, fair, sustainable and tasty food. Good Food Oxford was launched in December 2013 in order to help support the existing work of many organisations in and around the city to improve our food system, to catalyse new initiatives and collaborations, and to encourage more joined-up thinking, research and policy around food issues.

data.name: Free West Papua Campaign
data.desc:
The Free West Papua Campaign was launched in 2004 in Oxford, UK. We are a peaceful, public campaign, whose aim is very simple: to give the people of West Papua the freedom to choose their own destiny through a fair and transparent referendum – a freedom they have always been denied. We work with politicians of all parties, and also with other NGOs and campaign groups, both national and international, towards this aim.

We have no religious, party-political or corporate affiliations, and we are determinedly non-violent. Our funding comes from donations, the sale of merchandise, public fundraising events and occasional grants from charitable foundations.
data.street: Free West Papua Campaign;The Old Music Hall;106 - 108 Cowley Road

data.name: Extinction Rebellion Oxford
data.desc: We are a non-violent direct action movement demanding urgent action in the face of the climate emergency. Our members are people in the Oxford area and surrounding villages who agree with the aims and methods of Extinction Rebellion. We are proud conscientious Earth protectors. There is no Planet B.

data.name: EOF Hackspace Co-operative
data.desc: EOF Hackspace is an open community of makers, inventors and repairers who come together to share knowledge, tools and space. Our location at Makespace Oxford offers us a workshop space to work on all kinds of projects, including collaborations with Brookes University, Oxfordshire County Library, the Ashmolean Museum and more. We offer workshops in a variety of topics including 3D printing, digital electronics (Arduino and Raspberry Pi), special makeup effects, laser etching wood and plastics, and as our membership grows we will adapt to the interests of our members.

data.name: East Oxford Famers' & Comunity Market
data.desc:
East Oxford Farmers' & Community Market started in August 2006 and is a non-profit Community Benefit Society run by a committee and a group of volunteers.
The market is a provides food staples such as bread, eggs, milk, vegetables, cheese, meats, as well as dried foods, other food products, and a café. The market also provides refills for cleaning supplies as well as non food items such as jewellery, clothing, books, antiques, and plastic free products. Most food producers are from within 30 miles of Oxford and the market also includes local small businesses. The market is wheelchair accessible both inside and outside.
data.street: East Oxford Primary School;32A Union Street

data.name: East Oxford Community Association
data.desc:
Providing opportunities for education, recreation, leisure and social welfare
Prioritising those who are socially disadvantaged in our local community
The objects of East Oxford Community Association are:
The advancement of citizenship and community development, the provision of recreational facilities and the organisation of recreational activities with the object of improving the conditions of life of the inhabitants of East Oxford and its environs in the City of Oxford.

data.name: Dragonfly Housing Co-operative
data.desc: Dragonfly is a Housing Co-operative with a mission to provide a fair-priced, democratically-controlled home, whilst encouraging its residents to contribute to various environmental and social justice campaigns. Dragonfly is a member of the Radical Routes network of radical co-operatives, whose members are also committed to working for positive social change. The network is made up mainly of housing co-operatives of various sizes (none with more than 17 members), a few workers co-ops and a couple of social centres.

data.name: Cultivate Oxfordshire
data.desc:
Cultivate is all about bringing people together to create a better food system for Oxford. Better for everyone who eats food, better for everyone who grows food, and better for the planet.
We have experience running a market garden on 10 acres of land just outside Oxford on the Earth Trust farm, but now focus on partnering with local growers, producers and farmers to provide the people of Oxford with local, ethical delicious produce via our our weekly online market and farmers market stall. We work to involve more people in local food by building new routes to market for local producers and creating a vibrant and wide-ranging movement for local food in Oxford.

data.name: Communi-tea Cafe
data.desc: A friendly community cafe in Blackbird Leys serving breakfasts and tasty Caribbean food.

data.name: Common Ground Café & Workspace
data.desc:
Common Ground is a social enterprise pop-up café and workspace where people can stay as long as they like.  (Free wifi and power, but buy something to keep us afloat.)  
Our social purpose is to support student mental health by providing a relatively quiet space where people can come and just “be” on their own terms.  Less lonely than your room and more connected with society than the college library.  We have time to be friendly and welcoming.  
However, we “create community” and have morphed into a social space for this part of Jericho.
We host many different events in the evenings and for groups looking for somewhere to meet and have yoga twice a day too.
Everything is as sustainable as possible and is second hand, upcycled, made or donated.

data.name: Campaign for Real Farming and Food Culture
data.desc:
The campaign exists to help create "convivial societies within a flourishing biosphere" by bringing about an agrarian renaissance based on the principals and practices of "Real Farming".  Real farming is defined as “Farming that is expressly designed to provide everyone everywhere with food of the highest quality, forever, without wrecking the rest of the world”. 
The campaign seeks to bring about the necessary changes along  four pathways: farm practice based on agroecology; the introduction of food sovereignty whereby individuals and communities have charge of their own food supply; economic democracy - essentially a tripartite mixed economy, with cooperation and social enterprise key drivers; and respect for traditional knowledge including attitudes towards ownership of land.

data.name: CAG Project
data.desc: CAG Oxfordshire is a network of voluntary groups and community led businesses working together to improve the wellbeing of people and the environment within Oxfordshire.

data.name: Broken Spoke Bike Co-op
data.desc: The Broken Spoke Bike Co-op is a community business that aims to create an open, inclusive, collaborative and environmentally aware fixing & cycling community in Oxford(shire) by enabling people from all backgrounds to fix and ride cycles.

data.name: Botley community fridge
data.desc: The Botley community fridge is a fridge in St. P&P church, into which anyone can put food and from which anyone can take food.  Mostly the food is surplus food from supermarkets that is picked up by volunteers, and the food is taken by people in need including many rough sleepers.  It's a win-win: environmental and social.  There is shelving next to the fridge with non-perishables that are donated by several food banks, who see the fridge as serving the same clientele that they would normally serve.

data.name: Banbury Community Action Group
data.desc:
Banbury Community Action Group was set up in 2013 to run free local community projects on food, waste, transport and energy.

We meet 1st Tuesday of the month at 4 Ale and Gin, Butchers Row, Banbury and occasionally other locations around the town.

There are always lots of projects on the go including our Community Edible Garden, Give or Take events and work in the Community Orchard.  We are always looking for new people to join us and get involved in a project or start a new one!

data.name: Aspire Oxfordshire
data.desc: Aspire is a multi-award-winning employment charity and social enterprise. We exist to help vulnerable people who are homeless, long-term unemployed, ex-offenders, people in recovery or those with poor mental well-being to move into the world of work. We give them work experience on our own enterprise businesses and the person-centred support they need to make their own lasting change.

data.name: Allsorts Rose Hill
data.desc: Stay-and-play run by volunteers to support families with children under 5.
data.street: Rose Hill Methodist Church;34 Singletree;Rose Hill

data.name: Agile Collective
data.desc:
Agile Collective is an ethical digital agency and worker co-operative with an experienced team based in the UK and Italy. We work exclusively with organisations that have a positive impact in the world, and our clients are most often drawn from the charity, NGO, education and public sectors. We work with open source software and agile delivery methodologies and place a strong emphasis on user experience. Our core technology is the leading open source content management system (CMS), Drupal, but from time to time we also work with other open source platforms including Wordpress.
As a company with a conscience, we contribute to our communities, minimise our environmental impact, value fairness and transparency, and ensure sustainability in our working practices.
data.street: The Old Music Hall;106-108 Cowley Road

data.name: African Families in the UK (AFiUK) and WOW Space (Women Of the World)
data.desc: A community Interest Company  offering Training, Information, Support, and Advocacy in Health, Social Care, and Education; to third culture British African children and their families.  These services are extended to other newly arrived migrant families.  We run periodic cross cultural parenting courses for parents, as well as a weekly Women's group offering training in healthy family relationships and female wellbeing targeting BAMER women.

data.name: Abingdon Carbon Cutters
data.street: St Ethelwolds House;30 East St Helen Street
